alert.note: Alert for Brazoria; Fort Bend; Wharton (Texas) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 14 at 2:31PM CDT until May 19 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Houston - Galveston
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Houston/Galveston TX has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Texas... West Fork San Jacinto near Humble affecting Harris and Montgomery Counties. Cypress Creek at Katy-Hockley Road affecting Waller and Harris Counties. San Bernard River near Boling affecting Fort Bend, Wharton and Brazoria Counties. ...Forecast flooding changed from Minor to Moderate severity and increased in duration for the following rivers in Texas... Lake Creek at Sendera Ranch Road affecting Montgomery County. .Additional rainfall is possible which could lead to increases in stage levels. For the West Fork San Jacinto River...including Sendera Ranch Road, Humble...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Cypress Creek...including Katy-Hockley Road...Minor flooding is forecast. For the San Bernard River...including Boling...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT FROM LATE TONIGHT TO FRIDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...San Bernard River near Boling. * WHEN...From late tonight to Friday evening. * IMPACTS...At 18.0 feet, Minor lowland flooding begins upstream from gage. Minor backwater flooding up Peach Creek in Wharton County threatens low lying areas. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1:15 PM CDT Sunday the stage was 15.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage just after midnight tonight to a crest of 19.7 feet tomorrow evening. It will then fall below flood stage Friday morning. - Flood stage is 18.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 19.7 feet on 03/06/2017. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Fld Observed Forecasts (1 pm CDT) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Mon Tue Wed San Bernard River Boling 18.0 15.1 Sun 1 pm CDT 19.3 19.3 18.6 &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued late tonight at 230 AM CDT.
